column4: Hey, so I'm installing ubuntu on sda2 (D:), it says that I have to allocate swap space
What do i do to allocate swap space?
you create a partition for it, it is part of the install process
those definitions mean nothing to linux
linux sees partitons, not drive letters
if you are using wubi then you will make an image oon the partition of your choice
if D: as you call it is a second physical drive you can use a proper install and resize / wipe the drive clean to be 100% ubuntu
wiping it will loose all data on the disks partitions
you can resize ntfs to make room for the partitions for Ubuntu, or you can delete a partition to make space
anoter way is to use wubi to install Ubuntu into the NTFS partitions and you dont have to mess with any partitions
do you want a shortcut to your docs sat on the desktop?
No, I just want a link to my home folder on my desktop.
cd ~/Desktop; ln -s $HOME .
that will do it
will it run from terminal?
$opera --> opera: command not found
did you run: sudo apt-get -i opera_deb_file_name.deb; sudo apt-get -f install
I just downloaded and double clicked the .deb package.
you need to use that command to install the deb, the -f install will satisfy the deps it has
Oh ok
i'd use the command line, you can see whats going on then
gui methods are nice but when stuff doesnt work you dont gte nice outputs like cli does
